image.altText: A crashed car against a barrier with police attending.

items.synopsis: A man who police allege stole a car before it was involved in a triple fatal crash on the Sunshine Coast has more driving charges laid against him.

title.children: Driver hit with more charges after horror Queensland highway crash killed three

image.altText: A ambulance is parked at the Alfred Hospital.

items.synopsis: Frontline emergency workers have accused one of Victoria's busiest hospitals of not meeting legally-mandated nurse-to-patient ratios, which they claim is putting the sickest patients at risk.

title.children: One of Victoria's busiest hospitals is understaffing its emergency department, nurses say

image.altText: qvm-historic-photo-1st-arrivals-xmas-1907-400

items.synopsis: Every day thousands of tourists and shoppers park their cars, then tread over the remains of the dead at Melbourne's Queen Victoria Market.

title.children: A Melbourne tourist attraction is built on a burial ground. Will a billion-dollar development plan desecrate or honour the dead?

image.altText: A man in a bucket hat rubs his face in frustration.

items.synopsis: England captain Ben Stokes says anyone who believes the team should have declared earlier at Old Trafford 'doesn't understand the game', as Australia retain the Ashes.

title.children: Stokes bristles at declaration critics and reveals his one regret as England fail to claim the Ashes back

image.altText: An aerial photo showing a Navy ship in the open ocean, with a military jet flying overhead.

items.synopsis: An aerial photograph obtained by the ABC shows an RAAF P-8 Poseidon plane flying over a Chinese surveillance ship as it headed towards Australia last week.

title.children: First image emerges of Australia's encounter with Chinese spy ship

image.altText: An illustration of a woman crouched on a hospital bed with her head in her arms

items.synopsis: Too many women are leaving mental health units in a worse condition than when they arrived, with some in mixed-gender wards reporting shocking treatment that has left them reluctant to seek further care.

title.children: Casey turned to a mental health facility for help after her assault. She left in a worse state than when she arrived

image.altText: Iceberg in the Southern Ocean, seen from a ship.

items.synopsis: Antarctic sea ice has usually been able to recover in winter. But this time it's different, with levels taking a sharp downward turn at a time of year when sea ice usually forms reliably — and experts are worried.

title.children: A once in every 7.5 million year event is unfolding in the Antarctic. And it has scientists scrambling for answers

image.altText: A man holds his daughter as he walks up a stone road followed by other tourists evacuating the island of Rhodes

items.synopsis: Firefighters struggle to contain 82 wildfires across Greece, with 180 locations in the country experiencing temperatures of 40 degrees Celsius and above.

title.children: Temperatures reach 46C as fires blaze in Greece, island of Rhodes evacuates

image.altText: A homeless woman in Phoenix tries to cool down by pouring a bottle of water over her head.

items.synopsis: Record breaking high temperatures are set to continue for Europe and the US in August, experts warn.

title.children: Here's what we know about extreme heat continuing to grip much of the world

image.altText: An aerial view of wreckage of a school gymnasium in China

items.synopsis: State media reports a volcanic glass roof over a school gym collapsed following heavy rainfall in north-eastern China, with the heads of the company who installed the roof taken into custody.

title.children: Ten people dead, one trapped after school gym's roof collapses in China

image.altText: A ranger sets up a beach closed sign after a shark attack.

items.synopsis: Fisheries authorities are responding after a man was bitten by a great white shark near Gnarabup, in Western Australia's South West, this morning.

title.children: Authorities investigating after man bitten by shark at popular WA surf spot

image.altText: A man in a high-vis jumper stands next to pallets with logs piled in the background.

items.synopsis: Timber milling is an intergenerational lifeline in Corryong. Many residents will be impacted by the state government's recent acceleration of the end of native timber harvesting, tipped for the end of the year.

title.children: In one of Victoria's most isolated towns the sawmill industry is shutting down, and locals are worried

image.altText: A mother sits on a black leather couch with her arms around her two young children.

items.synopsis: This refugee mother has waited for more than a decade to be reunited with her older children. Learning she'll have to wait a few more years has been devastating.

title.children: 'I need my children': Susan has spent 11 years fighting to be reunited with her two older children

image.altText: bales of redcycle plastics at replas site in ballarat

items.synopsis: New research reveals the extent of Australia's single-use plastic waste, as global leaders "negotiate" over a plastics treaty.

title.children: Australia risks mismanaging 100k tonnes of plastic as researchers warn of pollution crisis

image.altText: Stan Grant appears on Q+A.

items.synopsis: Veteran host Stan Grant has decided to step away from presenting Q+A. Patricia Karvelas will continue as host of the program for the rest of the year.

title.children: Stan Grant departs from Q+A

image.altText: Craig Reucassel in a high vis orange vest and hard hat and standing in front of a pile of plastic bottles at a recycling plant

items.synopsis: Australia, we're still in a war with waste, and while not all of the solutions rest with households, there’s still plenty we can do at home to reduce our waste footprint.

title.children: Australian households throw out an average $2,500 in food every year. Here’s how you can start reducing your waste

image.altText: A male, caucasian politican speakking at a press conference, infron of blank curtains and flags

items.synopsis: The government says new changes would closes a legal "loophole", offering more than 850,000 casuals who work regular hours a new pathway to permanent work.

title.children: Government to close loophole allowing employers to treat casual workers like permanent employees without benefits

image.altText: A blue Red Bull F1 car, turning to the right, on track.

items.synopsis: Red Bull has broken the Formula 1 record for the most consecutive wins by a constructor.

title.children: Red Bull breaks historic F1 record, Ricciardo in lap 1 crash, Piastri suffers luckless pit stops

image.altText: A mobile phone is held in a person's hand at the ASX in Sydney

items.synopsis: The Australian share market is making small gains to start the week, but all eyes will be on the local inflation data out on Wednesday. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: ASX edges up as traders nervously await inflation data

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX 200 and All Ords are both up 0.2%, which isn't much, and hasn't changed a lot over the first half of the trading session. The sectors moving haven't really changed either, although energy has extended its rise (+1.9%) while mining has increased its decline (-0.6%) as the big two (BHP and Rio Tinto) fall a little deeper into the red, -0.4% and -0.8% respectively. The big banks have become mixed, as ANZ eases 0.4% to $25.06 as the ACCC delays a decision around its proposal to buy Suncorp's banking business. Suncorp shares are up 0.1% to $13.98. Five biggest gainers on ASX 200: Telix Pharmaceuticals: +6.3% to $11.00 New Hope: +3.5% to $5.38 Reliance Worldwide: +3% to $4.015 ARB Corporation: +2.9% to $30.85 Whitehaven Coal: +2.8% to $7.205 Five biggest losers on ASX 200: Core Lithium: -13.2% to $0.755 Sayona Mining: -5.9% to $0.16 Monadelphous Group: -5.8% to $12.36 Allkem: -5.7% to $15.035 Pilbara Minerals: -5.3% to $4.61
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX still as flat as the proverbial pancake

children.content: The
ASX 200 and All Ords are both up 0.2%
, which isn't much, and hasn't changed a lot over the first half of the trading session.
The sectors moving haven't really changed either, although
energy has extended its rise (+1.9%)
while
mining has increased its decline (-0.6%)
as the big two (BHP and Rio Tinto) fall a little deeper into the red, -0.4% and -0.8% respectively.
The big banks have become mixed, as
ANZ eases 0.4% to $25.06
as the
ACCC delays a decision
around its proposal to buy Suncorp's banking business.
Suncorp shares are up 0.1% to $13.98

Monadelphous Group: -5.8% to $12.36
Pilbara Minerals: -5.3% to $4.61

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Treasurer is continuing a recent run of appointments to key economic institutions. After having announced Michele Bullock as the new Reserve Bank governor just over a week ago, he has now appointed Victorian public servant Chris Barrett as the next chair of the Productivity Commission. "Cabinet has agreed to recommend to the Governor-General that Chris Barrett be appointed the chair of the Productivity Commission for a term of five years," Jim Chalmers told a press conference. "Chris's appointment recognises if we want to build a stronger economy, then we've got to build stronger economic institutions and that means renewing and refocussing and revitalising the Productivity Commission." Mr Barrett is currently the deputy of the economic division of the Victorian department of Treasury and Finance, with almost three decades experience working on public policy. Previously, he also served as Australia's ambassador to the OECD, executive director of the European Climate Foundation, and as chief of staff to former federal treasurer Wayne Swan, whom Mr Chalmers also worked for. "His appointment comes after a rigorous merit based process which involved interviews with two departmental secretaries and the Australian Public Service commissioner," Mr Chalmers added. Mr Chalmers said Mr Barrett will start his new role in September, and thanked the outgoing chair, Michael Brennan. "He has made a significant contribution to that institution and to the national economic debate," he said. "And I'm grateful for that and for his time before that as a senior public servant and a ministerial advisor as well. "Under Mr Brennan's leadership, the Productivity Commission has delivered more than 20 reports to the government."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Treasurer appoints Chris Barrett as new chair of Productivity Commission

children.content: The Treasurer is continuing a recent run of appointments to key economic institutions.
After having announced Michele Bullock as the new Reserve Bank governor just over a week ago, he has now appointed
Victorian public servant Chris Barrett as the next chair of the Productivity Commission
"Cabinet has agreed to recommend to the Governor-General that Chris Barrett be appointed the chair of the Productivity Commission for a term of five years," Jim Chalmers told a press conference.

"Chris's appointment recognises if we want to build a stronger economy, then we've got to build stronger economic institutions and that means renewing and refocussing and revitalising the Productivity Commission."
Mr Barrett is currently the deputy of the economic division of the Victorian department of Treasury and Finance
, with almost three decades experience working on public policy.

Previously, he also served as Australia's ambassador to the OECD, executive director of the European Climate Foundation, and as chief of staff to former federal treasurer Wayne Swan, whom Mr Chalmers also worked for.
"His appointment comes after a rigorous merit based process which involved interviews with two departmental secretaries and the Australian Public Service commissioner," Mr Chalmers added.
Mr Chalmers said Mr Barrett will start his new role in September, and
thanked the outgoing chair, Michael Brennan
"He has made a significant contribution to that institution and to the national economic debate," he said.
"And I'm grateful for that and for his time before that as a senior public servant and a ministerial advisor as well.
"Under Mr Brennan's leadership, the Productivity Commission has delivered more than 20 reports to the government."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: I flagged this earlier, and it's by far the most important economic event penciled in for Australia this week. On Wednesday at precisely 11:30am AEST the Australian Bureau of Statistics will release the June quarter Consumer Price Index (CPI). The typical market forecast is for headline quarterly inflation of 1% and annual at 6.2%, down from 1.4% and 7% respectively in the March quarter. The critical 'core' trimmed mean figure for inflation, most closely watched by the RBA because it strips out the most volatile price moves, is generally tipped to drop to 1.1% and 6% for the quarter and year, respectively, according to a Refinitiv survey of economists. Westpac senior economist Justin Smirk released the bank's CPI forecast late last week. It's worth reading because it breaks down each major category and goes into detail about why Westpac is tipping the number it is. The forecast has also generally been pretty close to the mark quite often. Westpac's headline forecast is 1.1% for the quarter and 6.3% for the year to June, which is a touch above the market consensus, but it's core inflation forecast is on the average. "The Monthly CPI Indicator is turning out to be a very helpful guide to the components of the CPI and we have used the data from the April and May surveys to fine tune our forecasts," Mr Smirk wrote. "Despite the additional information provided by the Monthly CPI Indicator, there are still many significant unknowns we have to estimate." Having crunched those numbers, Westpac expects electricity subsidies to push down utility prices by 1.2% over the quarter, with holiday travel costs falling 2%, putting downward pressure on CPI. Healthcare costs are also expected to fall 1.1% as households hit their spending threshold to received government subsidies, while education is likely to be flat after huge price hikes in the March quarter. On the flip side, fruit and vegetables (+2.8%), rents (+2.4%) and financial and insurance services (+2.5%) are all tipped to have seen steeper price rises over the three months to June than over the first quarter of the year. "Overall, the June quarter CPI is set to confirm that inflationary pressures peaked in late 2022 and continue to moderate as we move through 2023," Mr Smirk tipped. "However, it will also continue to highlight that core inflation remains significantly above the top of the RBA's target band and is not likely to return to being within the band any time soon." Westpac is currently expecting the RBA to leave rates on hold at 4.1% when it meets next week, but says it will be another finely balanced decision.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: What to expect from the June quarter inflation data out on Wednesday

children.content: I flagged this earlier, and it's by far the most important economic event penciled in for Australia this week.
On Wednesday at precisely 11:30am AEST the Australian Bureau of Statistics will release the June quarter Consumer Price Index (CPI).
The typical market
forecast is for headline quarterly inflation of 1% and annual at 6.2%
, down from 1.4% and 7% respectively in the March quarter.
The critical 'core' trimmed mean figure for inflation, most closely watched by the RBA because it strips out the most volatile price moves, is generally
tipped to drop to 1.1% and 6% for the quarter and year
, respectively, according to a Refinitiv survey of economists.
Westpac senior economist Justin Smirk
released the bank's CPI forecast late last week. It's worth reading because it breaks down each major category and goes into detail about why Westpac is tipping the number it is.
The forecast has also generally been pretty close to the mark quite often.
Westpac's headline forecast is 1.1% for the quarter and 6.3% for the year to June
, which is a touch above the market consensus, but it's core inflation forecast is on the average.
"The Monthly CPI Indicator is turning out to be a very helpful guide to the components of the CPI and we have used the data from the April and May surveys to fine tune our forecasts," Mr Smirk wrote.
"Despite the additional information provided by the Monthly CPI Indicator, there are still many significant unknowns we have to estimate."
Having crunched those numbers, Westpac expects
electricity subsidies to push down utility prices by 1.2% over the quarter
, with
holiday travel costs falling 2%
, putting downward pressure on CPI.
Healthcare costs are also expected to fall 1.1%
as households hit their spending threshold to received government subsidies, while education is likely to be flat after huge price hikes in the March quarter.
On the flip side,
fruit and vegetables (+2.8%), rents (+2.4%) and financial and insurance services (+2.5%)
are all tipped to have seen steeper price rises over the three months to June than over the first quarter of the year.
"Overall, the June quarter CPI is set to confirm that inflationary pressures peaked in late 2022 and continue to moderate as we move through 2023," Mr Smirk tipped.
"However, it will also continue to highlight that core inflation remains significantly above the top of the RBA's target band and is not likely to return to being within the band any time soon."
Westpac is currently expecting the RBA to leave rates on hold
at 4.1% when it meets next week, but says it will be another finely balanced decision.

image.altText: A graphic showing an unidentified woman, an HIV ribbon, a visa form and stamp that says 'denied'

items.synopsis: Australia is one of only around 40 countries with visa restrictions for people living with HIV. Advocates want that to end.

title.children: Debbie's HIV status kept her from getting permanent residency. So she took on the government — and won

image.altText: a woman standing inside an aged care centre looking at the camera

items.synopsis: The sector warns delays in reimbursing providers has created a "perfect storm" in which more than half of aged care homes are operating at a loss.

title.children: Millions of dollars in delayed COVID payments creates 'perfect storm' for aged care homes already running at a loss

image.altText: A man in robes herds sheep on a harsh-looking steppe.

items.synopsis: The North African country has been battling through its worst drought in years, but that is not the only factor affecting food availability.

title.children: Morocco calls for Australian live exports, but response from major player 'lukewarm'

image.altText: A man in military dress and a woman in a pink suit and hat

items.synopsis: Juan Carlos was once a handsome young king who saved Spain from tyranny. Now disgraced and living in exile, his son Felipe dreads his potential return.

title.children: 'Always embarrassed by his father': Why Spain's King Felipe is dreading his disgraced dad's return

image.altText: A scene of a collapsed building with an excavator digging through rubble as people watch

items.synopsis: Authorities say the number of casualties could be higher as rescuers dig through the rubble in the city of Douala.

title.children: Cameroon building collapse kills at least 16 people

image.altText: Yevgeny Prigozhin's face is illuminated by a streetlight as he partially smiles through the window of a car, rolled down

items.synopsis: Russia has long been a "paramilitarised" regime, where the state can be challenged and undermined by paramilitary or criminal groups but not completely destroyed, writes Mark Edele.

title.children: Has Putin contained the Prigozhin and Wagner threat?

image.altText: A man walks in a heavily damaged cathedral

items.synopsis: A Russian missile attack on Ukraine's southern port of Odesa kills one, injures 20 and severely damages an Orthodox cathedral in the city centre, a UNESCO world heritage site, according to President Volodymyr Zelenskyy.

title.children: World heritage-listed cathedral badly damaged in Russian missile strikes on Odesa

image.altText: An F1 driver wearing a black shirt and orange hat looks into the distance.

items.synopsis: The Melbourne-born McLaren driver finished fifth in Sunday's Hungarian Grand Prix.

title.children: Oscar Piastri praised by McLaren boss after finishing fifth in Hungary

image.altText: A large group of cyclists pedal past the historic structure of the Louvre museum.

items.synopsis: It wasn't the perfect result for Australia's contingent at the Tour de France, but there is plenty to build on heading into next year, writes Sophie Smith.

title.children: As Vingegaard dominated the Tour de France again, our Australian cyclists have their eyes firmly on next year

image.altText: A man waves to the crowd from the golf green in pouring rain.

items.synopsis: American Brian Harman runs away with the British Open, but Australian Jason Day joins nine other players to have finished runner-up at all golf majors.

title.children: Day finishes runner-up at the British Open, joining illustrious club to finish second at all golf majors

image.altText: A middle-aged man in a suit pushes his fingertips together onstage in front of a black and white backdrop.

items.synopsis: Twitter owner Elon Musk announces a name change for Twitter as chief executive Linda Yaccarino says the company is looking forward to bringing X to the world.

title.children: Twitter to rebrand to X and drop blue bird, Musk says

image.altText: A young Indigenous woman close up portrait

items.synopsis: Experts say boosting the number of Indigenous midwives will help to prevent birth trauma experienced by First Nations parents.

title.children: Calls for more Indigenous midwives to make giving birth less 'disorienting' and 'traumatic' for First Nations people

image.altText: A large yacht in dry dock with stairs and a gantry alongside it

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police will allege the men were attempting to import cocaine worth $61 million on a yacht that travelled to Queensland from Vanuatu.

title.children: Two men extradited to Brisbane over $61m cocaine yacht seizure in Townsville

image.altText: A solomon islander looking back at the camera with a pensive expression

items.synopsis: Gina Kekea was a young reporter at Solomon Islands national broadcaster when militants stormed the studio. Now, 20 years on, she hopes lessons have been learnt as her country faces an uncertain future.

title.children: It was a time when armed militants roamed the streets. Then Australian troops came and took the guns away

image.altText: Pat Cummins smiles while walking out of the Australian dressing room with Usman Khawaja

items.synopsis: The rain played its part in getting Australia home at Old Trafford, but despite dissenting voices from England, this is a triumph fully deserved by Pat Cummins's side, set up by some wonderful cricket.

title.children: Australia's rain-soaked Ashes retention still worthy of celebration, but now it's time to win them

image.altText: Ariarne Titmus puimps her left fist after claiming world championships gold.

items.synopsis: Ariarne Titmus produces a breathtaking performance at the World Aquatics Championships, while Australia sets a new global mark in the women's 4x100m freestyle relay and creates history by winning a staggering four gold medals on the opening night of swimming finals.

title.children: 'Fearless' Titmus breaks world record as Australia enjoys golden night in Fukuoka
